STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 29, 2022
Ottawa County DHHS
12185 James Street
Holland, MI 49424
RE: License #: CP700201350
Ottawa County DHHS
12185 James Street
Holland, MI 49424
Dear Ms. Spanjer:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
7/18-7/28/2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections policy and
MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MIEP and your policy. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP700201350
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling, Designee
Kendra Spanjer, Director
Name of Facility: Ottawa County DHHS
Facility Address: 12185 James Street
Holland, MI 49424
Facility Telephone #: (616) 394-7200
Original Issuance Date: 09/01/1991
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): 7/18/22-7/29/22
Total No. Of Records No. of Records
Reviewed

in foster care since last inspection 0 0

since last inspection 0 0

since the last inspection 74 8
No. of children whose sibling groups were split n/a

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12213 Record Management.
An agency shall do all of the following with respect to
maintenance of required records:
(b) Keep each record in a uniform fashion.
6 of 20 total case files reviewed did not have all completed documents uploaded at
the time of inspection. Multiple documents were uploaded/provided after the files
were determined to be missing from the file. These documents were from different
timeframes over the past year.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R 400.12417.
3 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
required information was provided to the caregiver. The receipt of this information
would be documented on the DHHS-3307.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 7/16/2021, CAP Approved 8/5/2021
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
1 of 10 open case files reviewed contained one service plan completed late.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 7/16/2021, CAP Approved 8/5/2021
R 400.12421(b) Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
4

(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent’s home at least once a
month.
1 of 10 open case files reviewed did not contain documentation that a visit occurred
with a youth in the youth's placement one month.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as 722-06H
Renewal Inspection Report 7/16/2021, CAP Approved 8/5/2021
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS Policy requirements
except for the following:
FOM 722-6B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business days
prior to a planned change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case closure
date or one business day after unplanned court ordered
dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is
used to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns and
the safety plan, and any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
5

The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business days of the FTM.
5 of 10 open case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all FTMs were
held and/or documents completed and uploaded as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 7/16/2021, CAP Approved 8/5/2021
Interim Inspection Report 10/8/2020, CAP Approved 10/27/2020
FOM 722-06J RIGHTS OF CHILDREN IN FOSTER CARE
Within 30 calendar days of removal, the caseworker must review
and explain the DHS-5307, Rights and Responsibilities for
Children and Youth in Foster Care, and the agency's grievance
policy with the child, foster parents, caregivers, and parents. The
caseworker must be prepared to answer any questions the child,
parents, and caregivers may have.
After the document is reviewed the signatures of the child and
caseworker must be obtained. The parent or caregiver must sign
on behalf of the child, if the child is younger than 11 years old or is
unable to sign the document. The caseworker must complete the
information on the last page of the document with the applicable
contact information and provide all participants with a signed copy
and upload a copy to MiSACWIS.
Placement Change When a child under age 11 or who is
otherwise unable to sign the DHS-5307 changes placement, the
caseworker must review the DHS-5307 and the agency's
grievance policy with the new caregiver and obtain their
signature on the DHS-5307 within 30 days of the placement
change.
Documentation The DHS-5307 must be reviewed and re-
signed annually. The caseworker must document the review in
the social work contacts, and the caseworker must upload the
DHS-5307 to the Documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS.
4 of 10 open case files reviewed did not contain all required DHS 5307 forms.
FOM 722-08A ONGOING CASE SERVICE PLANS - AGENCY SIGNATURES
Prior to finalizing, the caseworker and supervisor must
review the case service plan and all linked assessments
and treatment plans during a face-to-face meeting. Case
service plan review may occur during monthly case
consultation (supervision).
6

The supervisor must review and approve the service plan
within 14 calendar days of the report date.
2 of 10 open case files reviewed contained service plans that were not approved by
the supervisor within 14 days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as 722-09
Renewal Inspection Report 7/16/2021, CAP Approved 8/5/2021
Interim Inspection Report 10/8/2020, CAP Approved 10/27/2020
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker
 Supervisor
 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are placed
apart
 Parents who are a member of a participating household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check yes
or no for the following when signing the treatment plan:
 I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
 I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
 I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan
and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review, and I will
have the opportunity to express my disagreement with
the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the
treatment plan, the caseworker must identify, and document
actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s
participation in service planning and compliance with the
treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
7

8 of 10 open case files reviewed did not contain all required signatures on service
plans and parent agency service agreements, as required. The missing/late
signatures included worker, supervisor, parent, youth, and caregiver signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as 722-08C & ISEP 6.33
Renewal Inspection Report 7/16/2021, CAP Approved 8/5/2021
Interim Inspection Report 10/8/2020, CAP Approved 10/27/2020
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business
days of change in caseworker and/or organization.
7 of 20 total case files reviewed (10 open and 10 closed) did not contain all required
action summaries completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 7/16/2021, CAP Approved 8/5/2021
Interim Inspection Report 10/8/2020, CAP Approved 10/27/2020
FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's
placement date to the following
 Foster care provider.
8

 Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult re-entering foster care.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
- Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
- At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
- At or prior to each placement.
- Quarterly.
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the
necessary information under law and Michigan Department of
Health and Human Services (MDHHS) policy.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
2 of 10 open case files reviewed did not contain all required medical passport
updates and signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as ISEP 6.49
Renewal Inspection Report 7/16/2021, CAP Approved 8/5/2021
Interim Inspection Report 10/8/2020, CAP Approved 10/27/2020
ADM 1030 ADOPTION CASE RECORD RETENTION
For both MDHHS and contracted adoption agency cases, the
local MDHHS office or contracted agency must retain all
adoption case records for one year after finalization of the
adoption. One year (between 12-13 months) past the adoption
finalization date, a contracted adoption agency must send the
original record to the local MDHHS office; copies must not be
maintained by the contracted adoption agency; see licensing
rule R400.12713-
Adoption Placement Record.
9

The local MDHHS office must forward all records (both MDHHS
adoptions and contracted agency adoptions) to MDHHS central
office within three months of receipt of file. The contracted
adoption agency or local MDHHS office must not retain any
adoption records of MDHHS-supervised children or dispose of
them in any way other than that described in this policy.
Records must be sent to:
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
Document Control Section
235 S. Grand Avenue
P.O. Box 30037
Lansing, Michigan 48909
Following the finalization of adoption, adoptive family files must
be retained in the local MDHHS office or contracted adoption
agency for three years and may be destroyed after the three-
year period. Any Criminal History Records Information (CHRI)
must be maintained and destroyed as outlined in SRM 200,
Fingerprinting.
The agency had several boxed of adoption files stored dating back to 2019.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Electronic signatures/typed in names must only be utilized, when necessary, not
as standard practice.
 When electronic typed in names must be utilized as signatures, the case record
must reflect either in case contacts or through document upload that the person
whose signature is typed in has entered the signature themselves and that the
document was explained by the worker. Ideally, an email from the signing person
indicating that the document has been explained to them and they agree to the
document should be uploaded. In the case a recipient agrees to the document
via phone, a case contact should be entered timely, a note made on the
signature line of the documents indicating the date it was provided and agreed
upon and by what method it was provided/discussed. A physical signature should
be obtained as soon as able.
 A parent should only be marked as "participating" when that parent is indeed
participating in case services. If the parent is marked as participating, that parent
must be signing PATPs.
 Be sure to document the "effective date" as the date the action takes place. Be
sure to sign and date at the time the form is completed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
10

 If a court releases a youth to a non-respondent parent immediately upon removal
without ordering the youth under the care and supervision of the department, the
youth is not considered a foster child per licensing rules.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
This corrective action plan was submitted in response to Renewal Inspection Report
7/16/2021 for which the CAP was approved 8/5/2021. The agency remains in non-
compliance with 8 out of the 10 areas of non-compliance addressed in that CAP.
Additionally, 5 of the non-compliances cited within this report have been repeats of
the past two licensing reviews.
Chief Administrator Assessment – The chief administrator assessment was
reviewed and discussed with the chief administrator during the entrance meeting.
The chief administrator identified areas of non-compliance due to staff turnover,
difficulty in hiring experienced staff, working out of class supervisors being appointed
during supervisor medical leaves, and continued difficulties maintaining compliance
during spikes in local Covid cases.
Staff Interviews – Staff members interviewed reported feeling informed of any
changes to rules or policy that take place in a timely manner and report receiving
support and assistance from leadership, when needed.
VII. DCWL ANALYST CONCERNS
No safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, and policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
11

July 29, 2022
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 29, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
